description.p: Some are born Mistoborns, others are made through a secretive ritual, consuming a bead of Lerasium, giving them the ability to consume and burn metals to access an unknown magic source, very rarely seen before.

Mistborns are usually secretive individuals who closely guard their secrets since obscurity and misinterpretation of their powers gives them a great advantage in combat. Another reason for this secrecy is the very real weaknesses of Mistborns, that are sometimes hidden or not shared with other Mistborns. Mistborns distrust and avoid others of their kind, since they represent the most dangerous enemies to them.

As a Mistborn, you almost never unleash your true potential or share your true capabilities with anyone. Mistborns have hunted and killed others for less. You exploit your obscure magic to catch enemies off guard and to enhance your preexisting skills to become an unmatched force in the battlefield.

sheet.description: Mistoborns are obscure individuals who at first glance seem like common adventurers.

description.p: You have become Mistborn by the swallowing of a bead of Lerasium and can burn various metals which alter your physical and mental abilities. This ability is known as Allomancy and its secrets are closely guarded.

You have become Mistborn and can burn various metals which alter your physical and mental abilities. You can simultaneously burn a number of metals equal to your Intelligence or Wisdom modifier divided by 2. Burning some metals requires a constitution saving throw, determined by the DM.
Starting at 3rd level, you can burn Iron and Steel without any hindrance. On your turn, you may use your bonus action to pull or push anything close to your size at a distance of 40 feet.

sheet.description:
Burn Steel and Iron without the need to succeed on a constitution saving throw. Pull or push anything close to your size at a distance of 40 feet.
You can burn steel 1d4 times (every short rest), without expending a spell slot.
You can burn iron 1d4 times (every short rest), without expending a spell slot.

description.p: Starting at 9th level, you can burn Tin and Pewter without any hindrance. You can greatly enhance your physical skill and agility by burning Pewter. As well as all five of your senses by burning Tin.

sheet.description:
Burn Tin and Pewter without the need to succeed on a constitution saving throw. Increase your Strength and Dexterity by 4 and movement speed by 20 feet for Pewter. Tin TODO
You can burn Pewter 1d4 times (every long rest), without expending a spell slot.
You can burn Tin 1d4 times (every long rest), without expending a spell slot.

description.p: At 13th level, youâ€™ve survived through so many ordeals that you face each new challenge with grim determination. You can add your Charisma bonus to your initiative rolls. Also, at the beginning of your first turn in combat, you may use a bonus action to take a deep breath and regain hit points equal to your rogue level. You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, and you regain any expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

sheet.description: At the beginning of your first turn in combat, you may take a deep breath and regain {{level:rogue}} hp.

description.p: Starting at 17th level, you are able to instantly assess every opportunity to seize the upper hand in combat. Whenever any of your allies makes an opportunity attack against a creature, you may choose to make a ranged attack against that same creature with advantage.
